SilentPinoy

I believe that LOCKED prevents the use of a units ability to dodge, i.e. Dodger, Tuck-N-Roll, Zig Zag or cover. However it doesn't change the units targeting the LOCKED unit's ability to miss because they can't aim themselves. Just my theory, since weapons have an accuracy rating, even 100%-150% misses tons.

[2765372]

What happens if you have more than 3 equipment on one trooper?
On june 13, 2012
Pause

You get a new button for that trooper, the button says 're-equip'.
Each trooper only has 3 equipment slots available at any one time (or player owned trooper anyway).

Here is a list of all skills/equipment...
http://minitroopers.wikia.com/wiki/Sk...
If you see an equipment icon in this list then that skill will need to use an equipment slot.

An equipment icon will look like this...
http://images.wikia.com/minitroopers/...

For long term troopers it's a good idea to check the list before picking a skill.

The minimum to even have a chance for non-motorcycle vehicles is level 7, except for a jet which I dunno at the moment someone will answer eventually.

I don't believe you understand how the missions work. The daily missions are sanctioned daily that involve your units that no other army is directly involved(mission:infiltrate can be affected by other armies but they do not know you fought them unless they are told by you). Epic involves pitting your recruits and your main army together against level appropriate(or inappropriate) NPC enemies.

On june 14, 2012
Xtremekiwi

Is there a chance that you can tell what a good anti-spy trooper has to have? I only really have 1 decent anti-spy with On Point and Revolver, but he's too vulnerable to sabotage and with only 10 health...
On june 14, 2012
Team-Jay

Well the obvious perk to look for would be Suspicious, one of my troopers has that but his problem is that he has a Scattergun, which is a great gun, but half the time he ends up taking out my other troopers and missing the spy. The thing about Suspicious is that it makes you wish for more spies to be deployed at once, as your trooper will go mental and go on a rampage.

Failing that, my Soldier Boggy B is my spy-killer; On Point and the Famas are great for killing spies, but it's important to look out for something like Eye of the Tiger, to reduce friendly fire. Close range weapons, lots of initiative and disruptive perks (like Wrestler) are the things to focus on.

Failing that you can do what I did, buy as many troopers as possible and put all the sucky ones at the front as cannon fodder.


EDIT: I'm also pretty sure having a Martyr in your first wave would work as well.
On june 14, 2012
SilentPinoy

In general the best anti-spy guns are single target, decent accuracy, and lower recovery. So look at pistols and assault rifle types. A general practice for most armies to to prioritize 1-2 units to closest spy.

Of course being a heavy spy user I was lucky enough to have an anti-anti-spy unit in my midst.

I have a sniper in my first wave with Bait and 1 of my spies has Camouflage, so unless your unit has Smart the basic strategy may not suffice since your commands will be overridden.
On june 14, 2012

On june 25, 2012
SilentPinoy

Dang now I feel nostalgic. While looking through the old forum I got curious and started reading up on a lot of old posts. My forum duties started in late September of last year. I was of course late, thinking this game was nothing since I was hooked on Kingdom. I came to this game and the others because I was always tired of waiting for turns to refresh. I actually remembered about Muxxu/Twinoid because I played MyBrute back in 2010 with my friends because we wanted to beat each other up with our brutish avatars and gloat to one another.

Seems my first postings on the forums back when I had an army of 5 (2 Comms., 2 Spies, and a Doctor) back in Knockout Cup #3 for low levels. And seeing how everything was so different than now is crazy. Everyone was so unsure of everything in this game. What seemed like good choices always came back to bite us until we learned from other people's mistakes and overwhelming victories. I recall coming here because I had no idea what classes had to do with my future decisions and thought people would have insight for this game. All I knew was as soon as I saw a spy rain all hell on my meager 4 man low level army I knew there was much more to this game then giving a bunch of dudes with guns the command to go shoot a bunch of other dudes with guns.

This scar lead to the abomination that is my army that stands before you. I actually recall my unit Wizard having the choice between a Spy or a Saboteur and picking Spy even though Rogue was already a Spy because I just wanted Spies(I'm at 11 units and I don't have a single Saboteur). My unit Monk was also offered Saboteur but this was about the time when we learned about the Propaganda command(Many of us were sitting on army sizes of 5-8 at this time) and I had to have that ability also. Never knew how the mechanics of the game worked, For Science! I wanted to see if multiple spies would deploy and what luck I learned that they did (much later, but it happened).

Look at us now 9 months later. We've gained a few forum users and lost many more. I know for sure though they're always playing (because besides Caine(Harkoo) who is #1(with 11 troopers) there are 5 other armies with 12 troopers in the rankings above me in The Order of the Sainted Trousers) so there must be something in the forums that isn't appealing. For me it'd probably the intimidation factor of having no real output from a newer player considering a player like me can make a dissertation about high level strategy for a large army scaled battle between different kinds of units at all ranges and classes, while low level 3 vs 3 battles would seem so petty in comparison. And while I claim to have plenty of knowledge for this game and have made essays that would make you think I don't have a life outside of this particular game, I'm certainly not the best at this game. We all came from those crazy beginnings where getting 2 troops was the coolest thing when fighting only 1 random guy and ganging up on it. If you look back you can see everyone's excitement from achieving something, winning a mission, getting to a new raid level, getting class helms and oh boy when people started getting vehicles, the envy was everywhere. It's pretty daunting to see how far we've come and I hope newer players would share things more often, it's a good accord to see members who have been around and the things they say and how they change, exactly like in real life. I saw many of the members still here who didn't know what the heck Comms. were or how to change the order of their units.

Or maybe it's because new players know how to read old postings and learned from us talking and are building up based on that in an attempt to explode on the scene as a new force to be reckoned with. While it was possible months ago it's pretty well established how everyone who is active has a good army, there's a game that basically lists them in order(to a degree). But who knows, I still very much enjoy this game. If it was a grindfest I probably would've dropped it a month in. But the limitation that this game gives gave me a reason to crave it, to seek what it had to offer and to put time and thought into it and it was a good selling point for it for it's depth(or for me to artificially make it deep, this game has so much RNG involved it's insane).

The saddest thing is that even after months playing this game more than half the time I can't spell Saboteur correctly without having to use a spellcheck first.

On july 12, 2012
[1841726]

KomperaI guess it all depends on how you read it. Spy is granted at L6, so for me it's easy to read that the +50 Initiative is granted at L6, and that an additional +10 Initiative is granted for each level above L6. Thus, +80 Initiative for a L9 Spy.
This was my initial hypothesis but then reading more closely the soldier's and comms.' officer description and comparing them to spy's.....:
SOLDIER:
<Trooper> gains one Life Point for every level-up.
from experience we knew that a soldier gains a bonus of +5 hp at lvl. 6. so that's exactly 1 hp per lvl. up
COMMS. OFFICER:
+1 Communications for each level-up.
again, from experience a lvl. 6 comms. get +5 communication points. so that's exactly 1 comms. point per lvl. up
SPY:
<Trooper> appears in the enemy camp. +50 initiative points (+10 more for each level-up).
This statement is unusual, it specifically states the bonus +50 initiative points in addition to the +10 for each level-up and the way I see it it branch out into 2 arguments:
1. It is +50 with an addition of +10 initiative just as what SilentPinoy had stated
2. But there's an issue of the use of paranthesis and the word "more" , it can be also interpreted that the +50 mention was the initiative bonus from lvl. 1 - 6 and that there will be +10 more per level up, and the calculation is like what you have stated. If argument number 1 is to be absolute the statement should be more like this:
<Trooper> appears in the enemy camp. +50 initiative points and +10 (no more word "more" ) for each level-up).
HERE'S MY OBSERVATION AND BIAS CONCLUSIONS ABOUT THE INITIATIVE/SPEED SYSTEM:
Initiative is analogues to "time" in real life. (initiative = time) (200 initiative=200 minutes)
Rule:Initiative is the life line of actions: without initiative= no actions
For illustration:
walking = 100 initiative / minutes
aiming = 20 initiative /minutes,
positioning = 70 initiative/ minutes.
etc.
Rule:There are two types of initiave: (initial,bonus)
Natural Initiative: Each trooper is given an amount of initiative periodically for them to take actions. This is what makes the clocks tick.
Bonus Initiative: Disrupts the periodical distribution of the natural initiative and will make the clock stops (blue bar) to give way for extra actions has two types:
Initial Initiative: Will decide who will act first and how many actions that trooper is going to take before the natural course of natural initiative is rolled. This what makes the clock (blue bar) stops at the beginning.
Acquired Initiative: Bonus initiative gained through fulfilling certain requirements (frenetic, twinoid) and will gave trooper extra time. Makes the clock stops (blue bar)
-A trooper with on-point (+200 initial initiative) will gave a trooper 200 minutes more to work his ass off.
*Example 1: If the trooper decides to walk(100), aim (2), and position(170) he has lost 170 minutes and has 30 more extra minutes to aim. But he was intercepted by a trooper with motorcycle. Let's say that motor gives +50 minutes.
Rule: The trooper with the highest initiative will be the first to take action. But the initiative calculation is not at the end of each bonus initiative but at the end of each action. So other troopers can actually intercept and move even though the blue timer is not yet finished because maybe their natural initiative has already exceeds those of the "remaining bonus initiative" of the trooper. Exception: there are too many like pilot with motor intercepting an on-point trooper, etc. so this rule might not be true
For Kompera with his spy dilemma, the only analogy I can give you is in the case of troopers with the same-type of bazooka being called for "support". Some fires instantly along with the decline of the blue bar, while some don't. Most of the time those who fired were the ones with there bazokas above their shoulders already. Like what pickupsticks's said maybe you spy is doing something other than firing which requires him to burn up all his initiative.
Rule: A trooper waste his initiative if it is not enough to take an action that he likes.
For SilentPinoy's issue I can offer three arguments:
1.) the FATIGUE FACTOR: maybe repeating an action while the blue bar is ticking will increase (double/triple/etc.) the initiative required in doing it. E.G. initially, if the act of firing requires 20 minutes or 20 initiative, but if a trooper repeats firing while he is still in his "blue" zone it will require him an extra 20 minutes (total 40 minutes), then 40 minutes at the third firing (total 80 minutes), and so on.
2.) Acquired Initiative doesn't stack: If the spy has an initial initiative of 400 points or that the starting 400 minutes is his, and he pops his twinoid at the 100 minute, twinoid will gave him an extra 200 minutes a total of 500 minutes more (300 from the unused initial minutes + 200 from the twinoid) and not 900 minutes . Same as frenetic. Analogues to the poison effect.
3.) The spy's initiative bonus is Initial Initiative and not Acquired Initiative or Natural Initiative.

Most Underestimated Weapon
Probably the Sparrowhawk, with the right upgrades, it's a one-shot kill every time.

Most Underestimated Skill
King of Boules. Not only do you grenades never miss, I'm fairly sure it makes your grenades non-effective against friendly troopers.

Most Overestimated Weapon
The CK-Magellan. Yes, it's good, but not as good as people make it out to be. It needs a lot of upgrades to make it truly deadly and even then, it barely scratches heavily armoured troopers. Half the time it's not even loaded fully and will be switched for a lesser weapon rather than be reloaded.

Most Overestimated Equipment
Black Hole Grenade, it's funny, but a novelty at best. Also you have to constantly wait for it to be thrown so you can quickly press [space] to skip it in Extermination missions, because it freezes the game. Special shout out to Helicopter for this section, too.

On august 5, 2012
Doomys

I may as well answer my own questions



- The most underestimated weapon: I'm hesitating between Revolver and UMP. Revolver: With any aim boost, it becomes a great weapon because it has a large magazine that starts fully loaded. It has decent range AND it knocks down enemies.
UMP: The best assault rifle in my opinion simply because every bullet has as much chance to cause a critical hit as a sniper. So a 3 bullet burst = 3 sniper shots. Combined with hydroshocks it becomes such an OP weapon.

- The most underestimated Skill/Equipment/Specialization: Thermos of coffee. Since it affects action speed, it is worth the equipment slot. It saves a lot of time. It can make a default shotgun become almost as good as a scattergun.

- The most overestimated weapon: Heavy Machine Gun. Even though statistically it looks great:fully loaded, 8 round burst. The aim is just so bad. even with laser sights they miss very often and the 8 bullet burst is more of a curse because he can only shoot out 3 bursts before having to reload instead of 4.

- The most overestimated Skill/Equipment/Specialization: Comm's officer. You only need one of those and you'll be perfectly fine. (None will be OK too)

I'm beginning to regret getting Trigger Happy for Bard. Yes his Dual Pistols are now crazy deadly(In reality he shoots his entire load and kills 1 unit from what I've seen), but his CK-Magellan is crazy down in it's use. He gets a 1HKO and wastes a bullet lowering his long range interruption(Covering Fire + Bait) and this new ammo usage makes him cycle and reload to his single pistol instead of cycling back to the CK-Magellan to reload. It's gunna be approximately 2 months before I come back to cycle level Bard back and I'm sure a unit or 3 are gunna be screwed over by their level up.

Here's the order I'm going to level each of my units and what I absolutely and probably realistically get.

Well actually I've already leveled 2 units to 12 so first them.

Wizard; Choices: Minigun, Death Grip, Beretta
-I went with Minigun to suppliment short range assault. I maintain his DBS as his main weapon and so far it's worked out in cycling through in his kill sprees.

Bard; Choices: Trigger Happy, First Aid, Biped
-I went with Trigger Happy, see above.

So here's what I have left.

Sorcerer(Savior or Anatomy)
-Savior will of course increase my number and allow the chance to have a strong second wave unit(composed of mostly longer ranged units) in the last wave(composed to faster short range).
-Unlike my best sniper Bard, Sorcerer lacks an ability that enhances his 1HKO potential. Being a Doctor gives him the privilege of this possible skill.

Cleric(King of Boules or Sprinter)
-Cleric carries 2 grenades and well, he can't aim them at all. I like him with the grenades because it gives a longer range support while maintaining short range weapons so he can heal the rest of my team without taking forever to shoot or be too far away.
-Sprinter on the other hand would allow Cleric to support my assault and return to heal and retrieve a dead body with Savior.

Barbarian(Good Weapon)
-Barbarian already has good skills that would support weaponry, but only carries an Infernal Tube and default Sniper. Another weapon at any range since he has Sprinter would make for Barbarian becoming a good assaulter.

Druid(Bait or Sprinter)
-The only absolute difference between Bard and Druid is that Bard has the skill Bait. I would really make me happy is if I can carry my Covering Fire + Bait setup to my second wave, my Soldier Druid with a higher HP pool/livability and mobility would make him greatly effective in this strategy. My only issue would be that he has Camouflage and that would counterbalance it.
-Druid goes through his CK-Magellan clip very quickly due to Cold Blooded and switches to his Gatling Gun. As you can imagine he is slow as bricks. By watching Hero who has a Minigun and Sprinter I've see how effective a fast machine gun can be.

Hero(Anything Good)
-Hero is a solid unit but so far has nothing that makes him stand out. He finished my personal perfect team class composition(as close as it gets) and is a good assault unit. I just want to get anything to make him a much better game changer.

Monk(Hyperactif, Frenetic, or Amphetamine Shot)
-Monk's gimmick and overall effectiveness comes from all the speed skills(movement and initiative) he has. I want him to be the ultimate speed unit. I mean he's got Sprinter, Huge Calves, Hurry, Thermos of Coffee, On Point, I just want to see how far I can go.

Ranger(Anything Good)
-Much like Hero, Ranger is a solid unit without anything causing him too much strength or weakness. Unlike Hero I'm in no hurry to level up my Comms. points at this point, plus having full equipment and Survivor as well as a Motorcycle vehicle, getting any sorta of counterproductive level up choice would be bad.

Fighter(A movement or survival skill)
-Fighter has plenty of effective weaponry, just little for him to be able to unload it all on the opponent. He's basically my slow bruiser on my team(he deals the most raw damage out of my units, 1HKO don't count).

Rogue(Survivor, On Point, or Twinoid)
-An effective strategy I've noticed from my fellow spy users is that Survivor spies will share the incoming wave initiative bonus with an incoming enemy wave(namely me if they are the enemy spy). So I too would like to use this strategy along with Rogue's and my other 2 spies with Frenetic.
-More initiative on a spy means easy victory for me, if Rogue does get On Point and Twinoid he will be more powerful than Wizard.

Paladin(Same as Rogue)
-The problem and effectiveness of having 3 spies is that it solely depends on your opponent having 12 units. As the number one army in my division has 11 units(Caine) and the rest have 12(save for the last army with 11, I'm rank #3) and being active against units who also do not have 12 units, I'm stuck to have my army arranged to deal with my final spy as a throw away unit as he's built pretty much like my other spies. The only reason why he's the throw away is because he ties with Rogue in every aspect except for killing speed. A PAS with Compensator VS a Scattergun with Hydroshock Shells. If at any point Paladin gets an upperhand over Rogue in terms of initiative, he will take Rogue's spot as #2 spy in my ranks.

So this is my plan for the next 2 months. This is how far I'll have been for pretty much 1 whole year on MT, woo!

Well I never said he was a Lawful Good Paladin. Traits he share's with the Paladin Class

Mount = Light Tank
Heal Ability = First Aid Kit
Smite = Hydroshock Shells
Armored Class = BPV

However I agree with the irony. Perhaps Paladin is actually an Anti-Paladin/Darkguard going through the transition. They share similiar abilities that are oppositely aligned.

I do find it very cool that many of my units have parallels that are proper to their namesakes

Fighter:
Martial weaponry and combat specialist = Many strong firearms, strong damage dealer(Explosive Shells + Hurry, Heartbreaker),
Maintains immediate and lasting presence in battle = On Point, Survivor.

Ranger:
Skilled combatant = Abilities that emphasize agility and survival(Huge Calves, Tuck-n-Roll, Motorcycle, Take Cover, Survivor, On Point)
Decisive accurate striking(as with a bow) = Explosive and Hydroshock Shells.
Empathetic with nature = Talky-Walky(if considered a summon), Motorcycle(if considered a mount)

Rogue:
Swift combatant = Spy initiative, Charge, Compensator, PAS
Deceptive and deadly combat = Spy deployment, Frenetic

Wizard:
Powerful arcane magics:
-Teleport(spy deploy)
-Haste(Twinoid, On Point, Frenetic)
-Arcane buffs = (BPV = Mage armor, Tuck-n-Roll + Take Cover = Blur, Tank = Summon Monster VIII[Summon Monster IX is reserved for Heavy Tank])
-Various arcane offensive spells(DBS = Fireball, Minigun = Magic Missile[castor level 10]).
High intelligence = Smart

Cleric:
Divine magic
-Cure Light Wounds = Doctor Healing
-Remove Poison = Detoxify(Poison)
-Freedom of Movement = Detoxify(Paralysis)
-Resurrection = Savior
-Inflict Light Wounds, Mass = Grenade, Frag. Grenade
High Wisdom(access to better spells) = Smart

Monk:
Swift movement = Sprinter, Huge Calves, On Point, Thermos of Coffee, On Point, Tuck-n-Roll, Hurry.
Unarmed combat = Faceboot

Bard:
Minor arcane magics
-Truestrike = Heartbreaker, CK-Magellan accuracy
-Haste = Covering Fire, Trigger Happy
-Summon Monster VIII(I established before that it was VIII but Bards can only reach up to Summon Monster VI)
High Charisma(access to better spells) = Smart

Barbarian, Sorcerer, and Druid do not fit their descriptions at all.

Hero isn't really a class per se, but...
-his manipulation using diplomacy to disarm his opponents...
-his ability Bounce Back to get up while being knocked down is a heroic characteristic
-his swiftness, charging into battle with Sprinter...
-his overall balanced abilities...
...would make sense as well as several of his abilities that we attribute to normal heroes.

pickupsticks

I've started a couple of new competitions going. You may want to check them out.

One is a long playing "take over the world" scenario, which hopefully shouldn't require ANY admin work from me now that it's up and rolling.
http://twinoid.com/tid/forum#!view/47...
Golem's already off and running, so if you want to take part then don't wait too long or he'll have a strangle-hold on Europe and most likely Asia too.

The other is a "build an army" competition, similar to the Prize Army one I ran a little while ago.
http://twinoid.com/tid/forum#!view/47...
Players have several weeks to build an army of four level five troopers. This should be long enough that cashflow is not an issue.
There are some restrictions on the troopers you may take, in order to make the decision making process a bit unusual.
At the end of the three weeks there will be a knockout cup to see who wins. After that, everyone gets to upgrade their troopers to level six and then take part in another knockout cup, if they want to.

Full details are in each of the threads. Feel free to ask any questions there. Don't expect me to make any changes to the rules unless you spot a show-stoppingly bad problem... but suggestions are welcome and may be incorporated into future competitions.

Anyways I just realize that this game has a predetermined set of skills that you could upgrade for each trooper. Same goes with the additional trooper that you get. How did I figured that one out? Well I have this twin armies http://liliana3.1.minitroopers.com/hq and http://liliana3.2.minitroopers.com/hq which I have created and I find that the skills choices that each one is getting every time I level them up are the same even with the additional troops that I get offered. It doesn't matter which one gets upgraded first the other one would follow the same choices with the first. For example when I leveld up trooper Mooham Char from http://liliana3.2.minitroopers.com/hq to level 3 his choices of upgrades were Sturdy, Trigger Happy, and Dodger. After a few days when I upgraded trooper Mooham Char from http://liliana3.1.minitroopers.com/hq to level 3 I got offered the same set of skills.

So now I have a plan of leveling up and adding all smart troopers to http://liliana3.2.minitroopers.com/hq because he already had an advantage in level and credits compared to http://liliana3.1.minitroopers.com/hq and see which skill sets would be offered to him in the future. So when I am ready to level liliana3.1 I can give them the skills that would all be useful to my army. For example if my 3rd trooper happens to become another spy then I can configure him to have skills, weapons, and equipment sets for a spy and the possibilities here are endless if you already know the future of your army. Now I'm just waiting to be offered smart troopers and content on adding credits to them via raids, missions, and pick a fight.

Cleric: Sprinter. Simply because he only holds short range weapons and so that he can complete his doctor commands quick and possibly reach my spies with his Savior.

Monk: Frenetic. My swiftest and main comeback unit. He's basically like my spies.

Bard: Survivor. More zombies. First wave zombies to the max.

Hero: Tuck-n-Roll. Combos well with Adrenaline and need more survival skills.

EDIT: If this is a general case then binocular + hurry will have a severe downtimeXtremekiwiI think the problem with Binoculars is that it doesn't work if the trooper also has On Point until he uses up the 200 initiative.

after having binoculars for my scout i have figured out how it exactly works. Binoculars work in reverse with the command Retreat meaning if retreat triggers when the opponent has a minimum of 2 to 1 advantage on the number of troopers the Binoculars work when your own army has a 2 to 1 advantage on trooper numbers against your opponent. The difference is that Retreat only works on intervals of 400 ticks whereas Binoculars will work any time the 2 to 1 advantage is achieved.

First wave is my close-attack semi-auto guy along with long range support. He's usually quite effective, but the others are so-so. Most of my damage dealt throughout the fight seems to come from him, and he often scores multiple kills before he goes down.
Second wave are doctors and reasonable fighters. Making use of talky-walky I hope to deploy one doctor into the first wave to support them, but it doesn't always work out like that.
Third wave are the clean-up crew, guys with Bait to toughen them up in the hope that most of the enemy rocketry has been used by the time they show up. They're supposed to be able to pick off lone targets and stay out of trouble.
Forth wave only exists if we have a few Retreat orders over the course of the battle... which does happen fairly often. One guy in the third wave holds a talky-walky to try and bring in any retreated troopers to bolster the numbers.

It used to be that I'd have my main killing forces in my first wave, but as I came to realise they weren't up to the opponents I faced (and seemed to die before they could be effective) they got moved back into the second wave so that the first wave could act as cannon fodder, soaking up the enemy damage output, depleting their ammo a bit, taking the edge off their initiative advantage.
Now that I've got a capable fighter I'm moving back to having the first wave be openly offensive. If I get any more superstars develop as I level them up I'll probably bump them into the first wave too, and move the support guys further back.

On the whole at the moment I'd say the balance between my waves is about even.

http://zen-warriors.minitroopers.com/...

On december 9, 2012
SilentPinoy
HongKongFuiwhat I ask myself: in the "command my troops" section: is it important or an influence where you put your spy? I mean do we increase the chances of deploying him first when he is on first place and vice versa?

It matters, but sadly for none of those reasons. The main influences I can infer to the odds of a Spy Deploy is the amount of spies you have, spy's level, and the size of the opponent's army.

A thing you do want to make sure of is that if you have the liability handled of having your spy not deploy at all on the enemy line and instead he is still on your side. It really doesn't matter if you put him first or last if he's the only spy on your team to spy deploy if that's what you're asking. Also luck and probability is always a factor, if your spy inserted himself in their 2nd or 3rd wave or even as their last unit in line and you don't beat the 1st wave.

I get a lot of slack on spies because I have 3 so order really matters(as similar as they are). Not only do I face armies in which don't spy deploy fully due to numbers(only 1 or 2 spies correctly deploy), but 2 of my spies also have light tanks which also changes the spy deployment game.

On january 11, 2013
Doomys
CriptoMaybe your spy and hope for a good weapon? It might we worth levelling your pilots too in hope for tank.

No need to hope for a tank since if a pilot has a motorcycle and an other vehicle, he will have 1/2 as much chance of deploying with the other vehicle. Here is why:


Disclaimer: I didn't invent this theory about vehicle usage but I agree that this is the way vehicle deployment works. Keep in mind that this is only a theory and the subject is still very controversial. This is only the one I choose to believe in).


-When a trooper has 2 vehicles, he can only use one in a battle.

-Before every battle, the game rolls a dice to see if he will "spawn" with his vehicle.

-Obviously a trooper cannot spawn inside 2 vehicles. That would just not make any sense.

-so if both vehicles dice rolls end up positive (trooper will deploy with vehicle) then the game has to roll an other "two-sided dice" to determine which vehicle will deploy.

-Same principle is applied to troopers with 3 vehicles except that the system uses a "3-sided dice".

-I guess to resume this, the reason I say other vehicles have 50% less chance of deployment if a pilot has a motorcycle and that vehicle is because since the motorcycle has 100% deployment rates after level 8 (pilots only), so his dice roll will always end up positive for the motorcycle, therefore forcing a 2-sided dice roll each time an other vehicle's dice roll ends up positive.

(From what I've seen, heard and understood anyways )

I have a theory on that. In every recruit page there are three hidden text box right below the army name box. The IDs of the text boxes are "mid", "midc" and "tselect" respectively.
mid: A 16-character Base64 string based on your IP address (and probably browser). Used in the calculation of the army's recruit choices and new trooper choices.
midc: A 8-character HEX string, unique for every army. Probably a hash value derived from the army name. (This means the maximum number of distinct army is 2^32)
tselect: A decimal number which appears when a trooper is selected. Affects the skill tree of the trooper.

Recruit choices should be calculated by the mid value, browser used (if it's not already included in mid), the army ID that this army is created for, the date this army was created, the current date, and a small-ranged fixed random value r whose range is so small that it could easily be the same for two armies.

Twin troopers have the same tselect value when they're created.
Clone armies have the same tselect value when they're created, AND the same r value.
Couples are created on the same day for the same army, have the same r value, but different tselect value.

In the third battle, Mykel did not hesitate to pick up a Gatling to kill Blaze and then unnecessarily moved himself to kill Kin in the second wave.
